section.p: The Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol, successor to SSL, provides the mechanisms to ensure authentication, non-repudiation, confidentiality, and integrity of user communications to the services from public endpoints.

OpenStack endpoints are HTTP (REST) services providing APIs to other OpenStack services on the management network. All traffic to OpenStack services coming in on the public endpoints are secured using TLS connections.

body.section:
Notes
All of the example cloud models ship with TLS enabled on the public API endpoints. Because TLS is enabled by default, a test certificate is bundled with the release. Having this default cert allows you to bring up a cloud without having to worry about certificates. It will not match the IP address of your environments API endpoints, but you can ignore the warnings. Later, when you require a trusted certificate, you can add your own certificate and redeploy using the instructions below.
Keystone currently doesn't support updating an endpoint. Therefore the public endpoint cannot be changed after the initial deployment. This has the following implications:
TLS cannot be turned on/off after the initial deployment
The public endpoint IP address or FQDN cannot be changed after deployment.
Therefore, you will have to make one of the following choices:
Comment out the "external-name:" line in ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/network_groups.yml (so that IP addresses are used)
Assign a name to the "external-name:" line in ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/network_groups.yml (so that an FQDN is used) You also need to choose if you want TLS on or off. We recommend keeping TLS on by default as it cannot be changed. But if you want it disabled you need to change "tls-components" to "components" in network_groups.yml and comment out the cert-file.

section.title: Creating a Self-Signed Certificate
section.p: If you want to install a self-signed certificate for testing purposes that meets the needs of and HPE Helion Development Platform, follow these steps to create the cert, and then install it by following the installation in the next section.
section.note: Self-signed certificates should not be used in a production environment, they are meant for testing only.
section.p: The domain name in the certificate signing request in step 1 below and the DNS entry in step 2 must match, although the domain does not have to exist.

In step 2 you need the same IP address listed for both the DNS and the IP entries. The IP address is what is used by HPE Helion Development Platform and the DNS is used by . Note that as you examine the certificate output, the issuer will match the subject because the cert is self-signed. The requirement for the DNS entry stems from a low-level Python bug.
The example below shows you how to create a self-signed certificate named my-public-cert:

ol.li: Create a Certificate Signing Request (CSR) with a defined subject: openssl req -nodes -days 365 -newkey rsa:2048 -keyout my-public-cert.key -out my-public-cert.csr -text \ -subj '/C=US/O=Helion Test Certificate/CN=your.domain.com/emailAddress=test@ficticious.org/'

Create a file containing v3 extensions Ensure that the DNS entry matches any CN entry above and provide your IP cat > v3_ext.cnf << *EOF* [ v3_req ] subjectAltName=DNS:your.domain.com,DNS:10.0.0.1, IP:10.0.0.1 *EOF*
Self-sign your certificate openssl x509 -extfile v3_ext.cnf -extensions v3_req -in my-public-cert.csr -signkey my-public-cert.key -req -text -out my-public-cert.crt

section.title: Installing Your SSL Certificate
section.p: Follow the steps below to install the certificate in the cloud:

li.xref: If you are using a FQDN
If you are using IP addresses for external URLs

p.b: If you are using a FQDN:

ol.li: Create or obtain a certificate to match the domain name you are going to use.
Copy the certificate (containing both public and private keys) to the ~/helion/my_cloud/config/tls/certs/ directory.
Replace the contents of ~/helion/hos/ansible/roles/tls-trust/files/frontend_cacert.pem with the new CA certificate chain file that you added in the previous step.
Edit ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/network_groups.yml and set the values for external-name and cert-file to match the values for your environment.
Commit your changes to git: cd ~/helion git add -A git commit -m "Updated certificate and CA chain"
Run the configuration processor: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Create the deployment directory: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml

Complete the deployment of your certificate by running the playbooks below.
To deploy the new certificate: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts FND-CLU-deploy.yml
To deploy the CA chain: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts horizon-deploy.yml

p.b: If you are using IP addresses for external URLs:

ol.li:
Edit the ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/network_groups.yml file and under the EXTERNAL-API section comment out the external-name line.
Here is an example of what it will look like:
- name: EXTERNAL-API hostname-suffix: extapi
load-balancers: - provider: ip-cluster name: extlb # If external-name is set then public urls in keystone # will use this name instead of the IP address #You must either set this to a name that can be resolved in your network # or comment out this line to use IP addresses #external-name:
Commit your changes to git: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible git add -A git commit -m "My config or other commit message"
Run the configuration processor: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Note the IP address used for the public URLs (from ~/helion/my_cloud/info/address_info.yml)
Create or obtain a certificate tied to this address
Copy the certificate (containing both public and private keys) to ~/helion/my_cloud/config/tls/certs/
Replace the contents of ~/helion/hos/ansible/roles/tls-trust/files/frontend_cacert.pem with the new CA certificate chain file that you added in the previous step.
Edit ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/network_groups.yml and set the values for external-name and cert-file to match the values for your environment.
Commit your changes to git: cd ~/helion git add -A git commit -m "Updated certificate and CA chain"
Run the configuration processor: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Create the deployment directory: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml

Complete the deployment of your certificate by running the playbooks below.
To deploy the new certificate: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts FND-CLU-deploy.yml
To deploy the CA chain: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts horizon-deploy.yml

section.p: Note that the certificate that is installed by default, "my-public-cert", is linked to the name "myhelion.test". It is possible to deploy the system without generating or configuring a new certificate and come back and change it later, but access to the public URLS will have to use the "--insecure" flag to avoid "certificate mismatch" errors.
Here is the relevant section of the network_groups.yml file:
section.codeblock:
- name: EXTERNAL-API hostname-suffix: extapi
load-balancers: - provider: ip-cluster name: extlb # If external-name is set then public urls in keystone # will use this name instead of the IP address #You must either set this to a name that can be resolved in your network # or comment out this line to use IP addresses #external-name:
tls-components: - default roles: - public cert-file: my-public-cert # This is the name of the certificate that will be used on load balancer. # Replace this with name of file in "~helion/my_cloud/config/tls/certs/". # This is the certificate that matches your setting for external-name # # Note that it is also possible to have per service certificates: # # cert-file: # default: my-public-cert # horizon: my-horizon-cert # nova-api: my-nova-cert # #

section.title: Definitions

dlentry.dd: This name will be used in place of the external VIP address. This name can be an FQDN. This will be registered in the public endpoints of the services. As noted above, myhelion.test should be changed to your FQDN.

This list of services will be put behind TLS. Note this is only being done for the load balancer in question, which is the external load balancer. The components in 'default' are those services defined under service-components in ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/control_plane.yml. If you want to have a finer granularity, you can replace default with a list of individual components, such as: tls-components: - 'horizon'

The default my-public-cert is already part of the playbook but you can specify your own name. When you specify your own you also need to have the certificate copied in ~/helion/my_cloud/config/tls/certs on the lifecycle manager, as noted above.

section.note: Do not enable TLS on the internal load balancer.

section.title: Disabling TLS
section.p: If you don't want to use TLS, then you should change "tls-components" to "components" in network_groups.yml. Additionally, if you have a network_groups.yml file from a previous installation, you won't have TLS enabled unless you change "components" to "tls-components" in that file.

section.title: Configuring the cipher suite for public endpoints
section.p: We have set the default cipher suite to be: HIGH:!aNULL:!eNULL:!DES:!3DES. This is a recommended setting from the OpenStack documentation site. You may override this. To do so, open config/haproxy/defaults.yml and edit it. The parameters can be found under haproxy_globals list.
Make the changes as needed. It's best to keep the two options identical.
